review.title: RockIt: Exploiting Parallelism and Symmetry for MAP Inference in Statistical Relational Models
review.abstract: RockIt is a maximum a-posteriori (MAP) query engine for statistical relational models. MAP inference in graphical models is an optimization problem which can be compiled to integer linear programs (ILPs). We describe several advances in translating MAP queries to ILP instances and present the novel meta-algorithm cutting plane aggregation (CPA). CPA exploits local context-specific symmetries and bundles up sets of linear constraints. The resulting counting constraints lead to more compact ILPs and make the symmetry of the ground model more explicit to state-of-the-art ILP solvers. Moreover, RockIt parallelizes most parts of the MAP inference pipeline taking advantage of ubiquitous shared-memory multi-core architectures.

sections.heading: Experiments
sections.text: With the following experiments we evaluate whether and to what extent ROCKIT (a) reduced the number of constraints in the ILP formulation, (b) reduced the total time, and (c) exceeded the state of the art MLN systems. To ensure a fair comparison, we made a comparison with three MLN systems ALCHEMY (Domingos et al. 2012), MARKOV THEBEAST also with the ILP Solver Gurobi. Furthermore, we investigate whether and to what extent the performance of ROCKIT increases with the number of available cores of a common memory architecture. All experiments were conducted on a standard PC with 8 GB of RAM and 2 cores with 2.4 GHz, unless there are several established benchmark MLNs for empirical evaluation.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: We presented ROCKIT, a system for parallel MAP inference in SRL models that combines CPI and CPA. CPA is a novel algorithm that aggregates symmetrical constraints. Extensive experiments have shown that ROCKIT is more efficient than existing MLN systems. Future work will investigate further aggregation strategies and the combination of CPA with advanced inference approaches.

metadata.abstractText: ROCKIT is a maximum a-posteriori (MAP) query engine for statistical relational models. MAP inference in graphical models is an optimization problem which can be compiled to integer linear programs (ILPs). We describe several advances in translating MAP queries to ILP instances and present the novel meta-algorithm cutting plane aggregation (CPA). CPA exploits local context-specific symmetries and bundles up sets of linear constraints. The resulting counting constraints lead to more compact ILPs and make the symmetry of the ground model more explicit to state-of-the-art ILP solvers. Moreover, ROCKIT parallelizes most parts of the MAP inference pipeline taking advantage of ubiquitous shared-memory multi-core architectures. We report on extensive experiments with Markov logic network (MLN) benchmarks showing that ROCKIT outperforms the state-of-the-art systems ALCHEMY, MARKOV THEBEAST, and TUFFY both in terms of efficiency and quality of results.
